repnme.cdata!:
Mozambique - First Phase of the Roads and
            Bridges Management and Maintenance Program Project, and
            Railways and Ports Restructuring Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First Phase of the Roads
            and Bridges Management and Maintenance Program Project for
            Mozambique were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory; risk to development outcome was moderate; Bank
            performance was moderately satisfactory; and borrower
            performance was also moderately satisfactory. Ratings for
            the Railways and Ports Restructuring Project for Mozambique
            were as follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory; risk
            to development outcome was moderate; Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory; and borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned include: 1)
            precise definition and scheduling of works during project
            preparation; 2) policy and institutional reforms undertaken
            prior to major investments in works; 3) participatory
            approach to reflect changing priorities in strategy updates;
            4) appropriate financial management systems established to
            guarantee accountability and transparency; 5) strengthened
            procurement capacity; and 6) the use of local contractors as
            capacity is built. Of these lessons, perhaps the one
            embedded the most in the project design was the use of a
            participatory approach to continuously reflect changing
            priorities in strategy updates.

repnme.cdata!:
Mozambique - First Phase of the Roads and
            Bridges Management and Maintenance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for first phase of the Roads and
            Bridges Management and Maintenance Project for Mozambique
            were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was satisfactory.
            Some lessons learned included: Implementation delays due to
            underestimated contract durations at the design stage,
            delays in the decision-making process of the National Road
            Administration (ANE), inadequate contract management, and
            poor performance of some contractors and consultants
            resulted in additional costs, loss of economic benefits that
            were projected at project appraisal, and ineffective use of
            national resources. Therefore, it is critical for the ANE to
            carry out an assessment of institutional capacity and
            develop work programs that can be delivered successfully
            using agreed on time schedules. The coastal areas of
            Mozambique have few naturally available materials suitable
            for road building. The ANE needs to set up an information
            system that will allow management to monitor project
            performance and permit decision makers to take appropriate
            actions.  For the road sector programs aimed at using the
            sector wide approach with the concept of pooled funding, it
            is important to reach a consensus with other Development
            Partners (DPs) on the implementation arrangements
            particularly on fiduciary aspects such as procurement and
            financial management. The monitoring and assessment
            framework should include a time based action plan to carry
            out baseline studies, if needed, a well coordinated
            mechanism for data collection, and the agency staff with
            clear role and responsibilities for evaluation and reporting
            of the project performance biannually.

repnme.cdata!:
Mozambique - Roads and Bridges Management
            and Maintenance Program Project (Phase I)

abstracts.cdata!:
The Roads and Bridges Management and
            Maintenance Program Project will stimulate economic growth
            and contribute to poverty reduction through improved road
            infrastructure, better sector policies, and enhanced roads
            sector management. The Specific objectives of this project
            will improve the coverage and condition of roads and
            bridges; strengthen the country's capacity to manage
            and administer the road sector effectively and
            transparently, with efficient and sustainable institutional
            arrangements; establish finance mechanisms to ensure
            sufficiently, timely, stable, and secure flow of funds for
            roads maintenance, affordable at the macroeconomic level and
            for the road users; and improve road transport safety. The
            project consists of three components: 1) The civil works
            component will support roads routine and perodic
            maintenance, roads rehabilitation, rural roads civil works,
            emergency works, road safety, and engineering services for
            road works. 2) The second component will establish an
            institutional framework for the sector to ensure transparent
            roads management and administration and support policy
            reform. 3) The third component will support strategy and
            preparatory activities for Phase II, which involve revising
            and updating of the national integrated road sector strategy
            and preparing environmental impact assessment and social
            impact assessments for Phase II.

repnme.cdata!:
Mozambique - Roads and Bridges Management
            and Maintenance Program Project - environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Roads and Bridges Management and
            Maintenance Program Project will adversely impact the
            environment as a result of construction, and operation
            activity in the area. During construction, vegetation and
            fauna habitat losses will be mitigated by clearly marking
            the work areas with pegs, identifying trees for retention,
            and stockpiling shrub foliage for later use as brush layer,
            and seed stock. Soil erosion, and sedimentation will be
            controlled through the construction of diversion banks,
            filter structures - fences of windrowed vegetation - and
            sediment traps, and, in addition, vegetative propagation
            should minimize the disturbed area. Drainage construction
            should take place prior to, during, or immediately following
            road excavation, to minimize scour, and sedimentation, and,
            ensure that borrow pits, drain into sediment traps before
            run-off is discharged off the site. Topsoil saving should be
            the practice, to be re-used on completed road formation
            batters, or areas approved by the Supervision Consultant.
            During operations, afforestation practices should be
            encouraged; sound barriers should be installed to reduce
            noise disturbances; air pollution regulation should be
            enforced, particularly regarding vehicle emissions control;
            and, contingency plans should be in place for clean up of
            oil spills, fuel, and toxic chemicals.

display_title.display_title:
Mozambique - Roads and Bridges
            Management and Maintenance Program Project - environmental
            assessment : Final report
